• What is the Foundation Degree in Supporting Learning?
• What do I need to start the course?
<li><a href="#credits">What if I have level 1 or 2 credits
<li><a href="#nvqs">What about NVQs and City and Guilds
consist of and what assessment is there?
<li> <a href="#attendance">How often do I have to attend
taught sessions and how long will it take to complete
<li><a href="#after">What could I do after the Foundation
• What will the Foundation Degree cost?

The Foundation Degree in Supporting Learning is a part-time work-based degree course, normally lasting two years but may be completed over three or four years. There are flexible entry points. The required attendance is one session per week.

This course is aimed at people who support learning in educational child care settings and provides opportunities for them to develop their professional understanding, knowledge and key skills while working. The course content draws from and provides a strong academic underpinning for practical working experience. Successful completion results in 240 higher education credits, 120 at Level 1 and 120 at Level 2.

The principal aims of the programme are to widen access into higher education and to enhance the career prospect of those whose role is to support learning, by placing value on skills gained through working experience and enabling participants to acquire knowledge and understanding related to the roles in which they are currently employed. The course content is related to generic educational practice and issues affecting participants who are currently supporting the learning of pupils with a wide range of ages and circumstances. The development of the ability to engage in reading, reflection, debate and enquiry is an ongoing component of the programme.

The course provides a strong foundation of knowledge and understanding for all those who work supporting learning in educational settings, which may also be the basis for an alternative or work-based route into teaching or other careers involving work with learners in educational settings.
The Foundation Degree is designed to provide a route into
higher education for people without traditional qualifications,
but who have considerable experience of working in the fields
of education and/or children and can demonstrate the potential
to work at a Higher Education level. There are 4 entry requirements.
1. Be employed for at least the equivalent of a half-time

post (or the equivalent in a voluntary capacity) supporting learners in an educational setting (not with children and young people) and have been in post, or similar post, normally for a minimum of 1 year.
2. A letter from the applicant's employer/supervisor must
accompany any application. This letter must support the
application by confirming the applicant's involvement       with pupils (not children or young people) and state that every effort will
be made to support the applicant in undertaking the work
based activities required by the programme.
(Self-employed applicants must state in writing that they
are able to meet the requirements of the work based tasks
and provide a reference from a professional person who has
known the applicant a minimum of two years who can confirm
the applicant's involvement with children and young people
3. Hold a level 2 literacy qualification e.g. Adult Literacy Level 2, GCSE Grade

Note: Those wishing to achieve HLTA status will be required to present a Level 2 Numeracy certificate on the first day of the HLTA component of the course. Those wishing to progress to teacher training will require GCSE Literacy and Numeracy qualifications at that stage.
4. Hold a level 3 qualification e.g. A-level, NVQ3, CACHE diploma etc.. As an alternative, applicants may also submit a written essay &ndash
column2: please contact the Admissions Department for details.

column1: IF YOU ARE NOT SURE OF THE QUALIFICATIONS
Please contact our Admissions Department who will be able
have level 1 or 2 credits from elsewhere?

If you have relevant Higher Education credits awarded within the period of five years prior to entry to the programme, you may be able to use them as exemption from aspects of the Foundation Degree programme. You will need to discuss credit exemption with the Programme Director. If you are not sure about the credit values of your existing qualifications we can check them out.
NVQ level 3 may be used as entry qualifications as can
any level 3 City and Guilds courses. They cannot be used
as credit exemption from the actual Foundation Degree.
the Foundation Degree consist of and what assessment is
The Foundation Degree consists of twelve six-week courses.
You will undertake 6 courses, each worth 20 credits, at
level 1 and 6 courses, again each worth 20 credits, at level
2. Each course consists of 30 hours tuition time, and includes
specified tasks, activities at the work base and independent
study. The normal starting point of the course is September but students may also start the course at other points e.g. January or April.
Each course will be assessed using a variety of methods
such as short presentations, reflections on observations
or tasks carried out in your work place, short essays etc..
You will be given support in carrying out these assessments
as it is recognised that, for some people, formal study
may not have been undertaken for some time.
Foundation Degree in Additional Educational Needs (MS Word)

You will be required to attend a 3 day Pre-Programme Preparation prior to the start of the course. This will consider study skills, key skills and the context of the course. This will set the framework for the sessions.
• 6 sessions per module including independent study session

column2: 6  modules, 120 credits. The 12 courses are normally  completed over a 2-year period but students who wish to take a  longer period may take between 2 and 4 years&nbsp

column1: • Successful achievement of 12 courses results in award of
<li>Students who  complete one year only will be awarded a Certificate of  Higher Education (120 credits)&nbsp

Within each module there are five taught sessions in addition to one session independent study. Directed tasks, reading or tutorials may be set for the independent study session and it is expected that students will attend as normal. This session provides opportunities for tutorials and tutor feedback meetings.

Foundation Degree graduates may wish to progress by developing specialist skills or pursuing studies to Honours Degree level. An additional 120 credits are required to total 360 credits at Honours Degree level.
Those with specific subject interests that they intend to develop are recommendedto approach the programme directors of the subject courses they are interested in, to discuss potential progression.

Those who wish to progress to initial teacher training have various options. Download here.

This Foundation Degree is eligible for a Student Loan.

The Admissions Department will put you in touch with the
Programme Director or the Lead Tutor.

who intend to use the Foundation Degree as a means of entering
Although successful completion of the Foundation Degree
of HE does give you the relevant number of credits to enter
the Registered Teacher programme it will not give you the
appropriate specified subject knowledge to teach at secondary
The Standards for Qualified Teachers state that:

column2: those to be awarded qualified teacher status must,

column1: when assessed, demonstrate that they have secure knowledge
and understanding of the concepts and skills in their specialist
subject(s) at a standard equivalent to degree level to enable
them to teach it (them) confidently and accurately at:

column2: KS3 and 4 and where relevant post 16 for trainees

column1: This is one of a variety of standards which Registered/Graduate
Teachers have to meet but it is important that applicants
for the Foundation Degree of HE who are working or wish
to work in a secondary school understand the implications
It may be possible to use the credits from the completed
Foundation Degree to transfer to the second year of a single
honours degree in order to achieve the required subject
knowledge . This should be discussed with the Programme
